screens.headline: Greeks Calculator: Main Controls
screens.description: Adjust the inputs and watch the Greeks respond:

guided_experiments.watch: Delta increases, Gamma peaks at ATM ($100)
Theta explodes, Gamma skyrockets if ATM
Option price jumps even though stock didn't move

screens.headline: Experiment #1: How Does Delta Change?
screens.description: Set up: ATM call with 30 DTE. Move the stock price and observe:

scenario.task: Move stock price from $95 to $105 and observe delta changes

observations_to_make.insight: OTM = low delta (option barely moves with stock)
ATM = 0.50 delta (option moves half as fast as stock)
ITM = high delta (option moves almost 1:1 with stock)

params.teaching_moment: See how delta INCREASES as option goes more ITM? That increase IS gamma at work!

quiz_after.question: Why did delta change from 0.30 to 0.70?
quiz_after.answer: Gamma added to delta with each $1 stock move

screens.headline: Experiment #2: The Theta Acceleration
screens.description: Set up: ATM call at $100. Watch theta as expiration approaches:

scenario.task: Reduce DTE from 90 ‚Üí 60 ‚Üí 30 ‚Üí 7 ‚Üí 1 and watch theta

observations_to_make.insight: RAPID decay - this is the danger zone

params.teaching_moment: This NON-LINEAR curve is why buying options close to expiration is so risky. Time is NOT your friend!

quiz_after.question: Why does theta accelerate near expiration?
quiz_after.answer: Less time to be right = uncertainty resolves faster = faster decay

screens.headline: Experiment #3: The Vega Expansion
screens.description: Set up: ATM call with stock at $100. Crank up the IV:

scenario.task: Increase IV from 20% ‚Üí 40% ‚Üí 60% ‚Üí 80% without moving stock

observations_to_make.insight: Very high IV = panic pricing (earnings, crisis)

params.teaching_moment: Stock didn't move but option TRIPLED in price! This is why you check IV before buying. Don't overpay!

quiz_after.question: You want to BUY options. Which IV level is best?
quiz_after.answer: 20% (cheapest options - most upside if IV expands)

screens.headline: Experiment #4: Finding Max Gamma
screens.description: Gamma is highest at ATM + short DTE. Prove it:

hotspot.insight: THIS is where options are most explosive

params.teaching_moment: This is why 0DTE (zero days to expiration) options are 'lottery tickets.' Max gamma = max risk/reward!

screens.question: Using the calculator: AAPL at $180. You're bullish. IV is at 60% (IVR 80% - expensive). Which is the BEST trade?
options: Bull call spread: Buy $180, Sell $185 (delta + neutral vega)
Wait for IV to drop (miss the move)
screens.explanation_correct: PERFECT application! High IV = options overpriced. Bull call spread gives you delta exposure WITHOUT overpaying for vega. Long $180 call gets you delta, short $185 call offsets vega cost. This is professional-level thinking!
screens.explanation_wrong: High IVR (80%) means options are EXPENSIVE. Buying naked call = overpaying for vega. Bull spread = get delta exposure while neutralizing vega. Use the calculator to see: spread cost is WAY better than naked call.

cards.front: What did you learn from Experiment #1?
cards.back: Delta changes as stock moves (OTM‚ÜíATM‚ÜíITM). That change IS gamma. High gamma = delta moves fast.

cards.front: What did you learn from Experiment #2?
cards.back: Theta accelerates exponentially near expiration. Last 7 days = theta on steroids. This is the danger zone for buyers.

cards.front: What did you learn from Experiment #3?
cards.back: Vega can move options WITHOUT stock movement. Low IV = buy. High IV = sell. Don't overpay!
ATM strikes + short DTE (1-7 days) = maximum gamma = most explosive moves = lottery tickets.
